title: Understanding Formation Constants
text: The formation constant, Kf, is a measure of the stability of a complex in solution. It is related to the equilibrium between the metal ion, ligands, and the complex.

title: Breaking Down the Reaction
text: Consider the reaction M+2L⇌ML2. What does this equation tell you about the interaction between the metal ion and the ligands?

title: Identifying the Reaction Components
text: What are the reactants and products in the reaction M+2L⇌ML2?

title: Equilibrium Constant Definition
text: The equilibrium constant for a reaction is defined as the ratio of the concentration of products to the concentration of reactants, each raised to the power of their stoichiometric coefficients.

title: Writing the Equilibrium Expression
text: Write the equilibrium expression for the reaction M+2L⇌ML2.

title: Interpreting Kf
text: A larger Kf value indicates a more stable complex, meaning the reaction favors the formation of the complex over the dissociation into its components.
